title: 115_hr3284
content: The Act titled "Joint Counterterrorism Awareness Workshop Series Act of 2017" adds a new section to the Homeland Security Act, establishing a Joint Counterterrorism Awareness Workshop Series. The Administrator, in consultation with the National Counterterrorism Center and the FBI Director, establishes a Joint Counterterrorism Awareness Workshop Series to address terrorist threats and enhance State and local jurisdictions' ability to prevent, respond to, and recover from attacks. The Workshop Series includes reviewing existing plans, identifying gaps, and providing assistance to build capabilities. The Administrator establishes a Workshop Series to address terrorist threats and enhance State and local jurisdictions' abilities. This includes providing assistance to build capabilities, examining roles and responsibilities, improving situational awareness, and sharing best practices. Participating cities are selected based on funding received and requests to be considered. Individuals from designated cities are eligible to participate in the Workshop Series. The Workshop Series is open to local jurisdictions and emergency response providers in designated cities. Participants include senior officials, law enforcement, fire and rescue, emergency management, EMS, public health officials, private sector representatives, and others as deemed appropriate. Reports are developed after each Workshop Series to address key findings on lessons learned and best practices. The Workshop Series addresses key findings, best practices, and mitigation strategies. The Administrator must submit annual reports summarizing themes and lessons learned to congressional committees. $1,000,000 is authorized annually for fiscal years 2018 through 2022 for this purpose. Authorization of $1,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2018 through 2022 to carry out the Workshop Series under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents. Authorization of $1,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2018 through 2022 for the Joint Counterterrorism Awareness Workshop Series under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. Passed by the House of Representatives on September 14, 2017.
